analytic.title: High-temperature tensile properties of laser powder bed fusion Ti–6.5Al–2Zr–1Mo–1V alloy after annealing

biblStruct.note: Received 7 October 2024; Received in revised form 16 December 2024; Accepted 16 December 2024 Materials Science & Engineering A 923 (2025) 147700

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: TA15 alloy Laser powder bed fusion Microstructure High-temperature tensile property

div.p: Herein, the high-temperature tensile deformation behavior in the range of 500-750 • C for laser powder bed fusion (L-PBF) Ti-6.5Al-2Zr-1Mo-1V (TA15) alloy after annealing treatment has been investigated in detail. The experimental results show that the ultimate tensile strength (UTS) and yield strength (YS) of the sample decrease gradually with the increase of test temperature, while the elongation (EL) of the sample increases gradually. The reduction in strength can be attributed to the decrease in dislocation density. When the tensile temperature is below 550 • C, a pronounced work-hardening phenomenon can be observed. At temperatures above 650 • C, significant dynamic recovery and dynamic recrystallization effects lead to significant softening. When the tensile temperature is below 600 • C, the fracture mode is transgranular fracture, while when the temperature is 650 • C, the fracture mode changes to intergranular fracture. After annealing, L-PBF TA15 samples exhibit excellent mechanical properties at medium to high temperatures, which provides an important reference value for the application of L-PBF fabricated titanium alloy components in the aerospace industries.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Titanium alloys are an indispensable material for key components in aerospace hot end applications due to their excellent strength-to-weight ratio, excellent weldability and excellent heat resistance [1,2]. Among all types of titanium alloys, near-α titanium alloys, such as Ti60 [3], IMI829 [4] and Ti-1100 [5] are widely applied in high-temperature environments, such as aerospace engine components, owing to their superior high-temperature mechanical properties and processability. Ti-6.5Al-2Zr-1Mo-1V (TA15) alloy, a high-temperature titanium alloy, possesses a high content of α stabilizing elements, which endows it with excellent thermal stability, enabling its prolonged use at 500 • C [6]. The mechanical properties at room and high temperature of TA15 alloys manufactured by traditional techniques such as forging and powder metallurgy have been extensively studied. For instance, Li et al. [7] found the microstructure, mechanical properties and fracture modes of powder metallurgy TA15 alloy within the temperature range of 500-650 • C, revealing the highest tensile strength and ductility at 500 • C, and a transition from intergranular to trans-granular fracture at 600 • C. Liu et al. [8] observed that, during tensile testing at 750 • C, the flow stress of TA15 alloy sheets peaked at 10 % true strain, while the dislocation density continued to increase.

However, traditional manufacturing methods still confront numerous challenges when fabricating intricately shaped titanium alloy structural components, such as low material utilization and prolonged production cycles. The emergence of additive manufacturing technology offers an effective solution to solve the above challenges [9,10], since this technology enables near-net shaping of high-performance complex components, offering advantages such as short production cycles and manufacturing flexibility, effectively circumventing the limitations of traditional processes [11][12][13]. Laser powder bed fusion (L-PBF), a technique of additive manufacturing, uses a high-energy laser beam to selectively melt layers of powder, allowing complex-shaped parts to be built layer-by-layer [14,15]. This technology has not only revolutionized the fabrication of intricate titanium alloy components but also markedly enhanced design flexibility, reduced costs, and improved efficiency [16].

Currently, a large number of studies have focused on the tensile properties and deformation mechanism of L-PBF TA15 alloy at room temperature. In 2018, Wu et al. [17]reported that the TA15 alloy with hierarchical martensite and a high density of twins can be fabricated using L-PBF technology, and exhibits a tensile strength of 1422 MPa at room temperature, comparable to TA15-based composites. Cai et al. [18] conducted extensive research on the effects of processing parameters on the microstructure and tensile properties of L-PBF TA15 alloy. Jiang et al. [19] revealed the microstructure of as-built TA 15 alloy primarily consists of αʹ martensite, exhibiting a yield strength of 1296 MPa with a low ductility of 7.6 %, whereas after annealing, the initial αʹ phase is decomposed into α + β, leading to a significant improvement in comprehensive mechanical properties. In addition, some scholars have also studied the tensile properties of L-PBF TA15 alloy at 500 • C by single-step annealing [20]. The results indicate that the samples after annealing at 950 • C exhibit significantly better strength and ductility compared to the as-cast TA15 alloy. Cai et al. [18] also discovered that L-PBF TA15 titanium alloy can obtain attractive mechanical properties at 500 • C after annealing.

To date, the tensile properties of the L-PBF TA15 alloy after annealing in high-temperature environments exceeding 500 • C have not been investigated. Therefore, in order to fill this gap, the deformation behavior and softening mechanism of the L-PBF TA15 alloy after annealing in the temperature range of 500-750 • C were studied. The softening processes and fracture mode in this temperature range have been identified, and the relationship between grain boundary strength and temperature has also been elucidated. This research is expected to expand the application range of L-PBF TA15 alloy at high temperatures and improve the safety of use.

div.head: Powders and sample preparation
div.p: The powders used in the L-PBF process are produced by atomization technology. Fig. 1a andb show the microscopic morphology and particle size distribution of spherical powders, respectively. The powders exhibit good sphericity with D 10 , D 50 and D 90 values of 18 μm, 30 μm and 53 μm, respectively.

In this study, the L-PBF system selected was the HIT-M290 (China) equipment, equipped with an IPG 500W laser with a spot diameter of 80 μm. The fabrication of samples was conducted on a Ti-6Al-4V substrate.

The processing parameters include laser power: 300W, scanning speed: 1000 mm/s, hatch spacing: 110 μm, layer thickness: 30 μm, and 90 • rotation scanning strategy. After processing, the samples were excised from the substrates using wire electrical discharge machining. The TA15 alloys produced by L-PBF typically consist of a fully αʹ martensitic structure [21]. The αʹ phase is known to decompose at temperatures above 400 • C [22,23]. To ensure stability in mechanical properties at elevated temperatures, heat treatment was conducted in a resistance furnace, with the samples coated with a ceramic protective layer to prevent oxidation. The heating rate was set at 10 • C/min, followed by a 2-h dwell at a temperature of 850 • C, and then cooled by air.

div.head: Microstructural characterizations
div.p: Before microstructure analysis, the samples were ground with SiC sandpapers and then polished with silica suspension. The polished surface was etched with Kroll reagent. Phase analysis was performed utilizing a PANalytical X'Pert X-ray diffractometer. Microstructural observations were carried out using an optical microscope (OM) and a Zeiss SUPR55 SEM. Before electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) analysis, the samples underwent electrolytic polishing, with the electrolyte composed of 6 % perchloric acid, 34 % butanol, and 60 % methanol. Electrolytic polishing was conducted at -20 • C, with a voltage of 27 V and a polishing duration of 2 min.

div.head: Tensile tests
div.p: Fig. 2b illustrates the extraction locations of tensile samples. Using a high-temperature dynamic elastic modulus and damping analyzer, the elastic modulus and shear modulus of the sample were experimentally measured in the temperature range of 25-750 • C. The high-temperature tensile tests were conducted using an INSTRON 5500R apparatus, with the strain rate set at 1 × 10 3 s -1 . Before the experiment, the tensile apparatus was preheated to the target temperature, following which the sample was inserted and maintained at a constant temperature for 10 min before the tensile test. To minimize experimental errors, three samples were subjected to tensile tests under identical conditions at each temperature. Furthermore, the microstructure near the fracture surfaces of the samples was examined using both EBSD and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The TEM sample was thinned to an approximate thickness of 40 μm using SiC sandpapers, followed by ion milling with a Gatan 695 instrument.

div.head: Microstructure of as-built and annealed TA15 alloys
div.p: Fig. 3 illustrates the XRD patterns of both as-built and annealed samples, both of which exhibited diffraction peaks characteristic of the hexagonal close-packed (HCP) structure. The HCP phases in the as-built and annealed samples can be identified as the αʹ phase and the α phase, respectively. Extensive studies have found that the diffraction peak positions of two phases are extremely close, which is attributed to their similar lattice parameters [21,24]. The diffraction peak characteristics of β phase are also identified in samples after annealing. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) values for both αʹ and α phases are presented in Table 1. It can be seen from Table 1 that the αʹ phase shows a shift towards bigger angles compared to the α phase. In addition, as indicated by Table 1, the FWHM of the as-built sample is greater than that of the annealed sample. Since the solute elements are not able to diffuse sufficiently due to the rapid cooling rate during the processing, the α phase (Al) and β phase (Mo and V) stabilizing elements are extensively distributed within the αʹ martensitic, forming a supersaturated solid solution with significant lattice distortion. Consequently, the diffraction peaks of the as-built TA15 samples are broader compared to those of the annealed sample. Besides, according to the Bragg equation, a decrease in lattice constant results in a shift of diffraction peaks towards higher angles [25,26]. Because the atomic radius of Al (0.143 nm) is larger than those of V and Mo (0.132 nm and 0.136 nm, respectively), the lattice constant decreases, causing the diffraction peaks to shift towards higher angles [27]. Therefore, the analysis of XRD diffraction peak angles and FWHM confirms that the as-built TA15 alloy consists of αʹ phase, which can be decomposed into α + β after annealing treatment. No significant defects are detected in Fig. 4a andb. By employing a 90 • rotation scanning strategy, a checkerboard pattern of prior-β grains (PBGs) can be observed on the XOY plane, consistent with previous research findings [28,29]. Due to the maximum thermal gradient direction is parallel to the building direction, the PBGs predominantly grow epitaxially along this direction (Fig. 4b). In addition, the high Fig. 3. XRD pattern of as-built and annealed samples.

div.head: Table 1
div.p: The FWHM data of the as-built and annealed TA15 alloys. cooling rate and complex thermal cycle history inherent in L-PBF processing result in the formation of the substantial quantity of fine acicular αʹ in the PBGs [30]. Owing to the requirement for the phase transformation to conform to the Burgers Orientation Relationship (BOR), it is observed that the acicular martensite exhibits an angle of 45 • with respect to the PBG boundaries [31]. Fig. 3d shows the high-magnification SEM image of annealed sample. Based on XRD results, the fine needle-like αʹ martensite transitioned into lamellar α + β phases after annealing treatment. Fig. 3e and f illustrate the inverse pole figure (IPF) and misorientation angle distribution after annealing, and the microstructure of annealed sample follows the BOR relationship.

div.head: High-temperature mechanical properties and fracture surface after annealing
div.p: The engineering stress-strain curves of annealed TA15 alloys in the range of 500-750 • C are depicted in Fig. 5. Table 2 presents the detailed tensile properties of these samples. At 500 • C, the YS of the sample is 564 MPa, and its EL is 18.5 %. At the highest tested temperature of 750 • C, the YS decreases to 143 MPa, whereas the EL increases to 52.9 %. It is particularly noteworthy that at 500 • C and 550 • C, the stress increases with the applied load to reach a peak value, followed by a rapid decrease until fracture occurs, as depicted in Fig. 5. It can be inferred that at temperatures of 500 and 550 • C, the deformation process is predominantly governed by work hardening, with the increase in flow stress attributed to a rise in dislocation density. Due to the relatively low tensile temperature, the dynamic softening is significantly restricted. When the tensile temperature reaches 600 • C, a softening phenomenon occurs, characterized by the flow stress reaching a peak before gradually decreasing until fracture occurs. This deformation behavior indicates that dynamic recovery (DRV) and dynamic recrystallization (DRX) replace work hardening as the predominant factor in determining the deformation behavior. In the temperature range of 650-750 • C, the stress-strain curve shows a similar pattern, and when the strain exceeds the UTS point, the flow stress slowly decreases until the fracture.

To accurately determine the transition of softening mechanisms, the Arrhenius equation was employed for description. The Arrhenius equation serves as a classical method for elucidating the relationship between temperature and flow stress during the high-temperature deformation [32]:
div.formula: ε = Aσ n exp ( - Q RT )(1)
div.p: where, ε is the strain rate, A is the material coefficients, σ is the flow stress, and n is the stress index, it can be expressed as n = 1/m, m is the strain-rate sensitivity index and Q is the deformation activation energy (KJ/mol). In this study, with a constant strain rate, by taking the natural logarithm of both sides of Equation ( 1):

Fig. 6 depicts the correlation between the lnσ and the reciprocal of temperature (1/T). σ y is yield stress, and σ p is peak stress. A linear fitting method was utilized to analyze two distinct temperature ranges: 500-600 • C and 600-750 • C. The findings demonstrate a definite linear relationship between lnσ y , lnσ p and 1/T. The study found that the range of n is 3.0-7.7 [33], with calculated values of Q ranging from 48.84 to 125.36 kJ/mol (at 500-600 • C) and 201.71-517.72 kJ/mol (at 650-750 • C). Within the range of 500-600 • C, the Q values are close to the activation energy for self-diffusion in α-titanium (97 kJ/mol) [34].

Given that DRV is believed to occur via dislocation glide, climb, or cross-slip, the required activation energy is close to the value of the self-diffusion activation energy. At temperatures of 650-750 • C, the Q values are significantly higher than the activation energy for self-diffusion in α-titanium or β-titanium (153 kJ/mol). A reasonable explanation is that DRX becomes more dominant above 650 • C, exerting a substantial influence on the activation energy. Hence, the critical temperature for high-temperature deformation can be determined to be between 600 and 650 • C. At deformation temperatures below 600 • C, the discrepancy between σ y and σ p amplifies with decreasing temperature, indicative of enhanced work-hardening capacity. In contrast, when the temperature surpasses 600 • C, the discrepancy between σ y and σ p markedly diminishes on account of the pronounced influence of DRV and DRX. The tensile fracture morphologies at various temperatures are shown in Fig. 7. For all samples, the fracture surfaces exhibit a dense distribution of dimples, characteristic of ductile fracture. At 500-600 • C, the fracture surfaces display numerous cleavage steps with a large number of pits on the step surfaces. This indicates that within this temperature range, the grain boundaries possess higher strength than the grains themselves, leading to a trans-granular fracture mode. As the tensile temperature reaches 650 • C, a distinct change in the fracture morphology can be observed. The vertically aligned columnar fracture surfaces correspond to the shape of the columnar grains mentioned in Section 3.1, suggesting a transition from trans-granular to intergranular fracture. The PBG boundary in Fig. 7q is easy to identify. As the tensile temperature increases, the grain boundary strength becomes lower than that of the grain. In the case of continuous application of force, once cracks begin to appear at the PBG boundaries, since there is no lamellar grain obstruction, the cracks can easily spread along the PBGs to form catastrophic cracks, resulting in intergranular fracture [35]. At a tensile temperature of 750 • C, severe oxidation results in a rough surface, however, deep dimples are still evident.

div.head: Microstructures evolution after tensile
div.p: To understand the deformation mechanisms of samples at various temperatures, the fracture surfaces of the tensile samples were analyzed using EBSD and TEM. Fig. 8 illustrates the IPF near the fracture surface of annealed TA15 alloys at different temperatures. When the tensile temperature is 550-700 • C, the lamellar α grains are significantly elongated in the tensile direction. At 750 • C, the original lamellar α grains became epitaxial α grains, indicating that complete DRX occurred. Fig. 9 depicts the kernel average misorientation (KAM) maps. Notably, the KAM value exhibits a gradual decrease with increasing tensile temperature. Typically, geometrically necessary dislocations (ρ GND ) can be estimated using the KAM value through the following equation [36]:

where KAM ave corresponds to the average value of KAM in the selected zone, μ stands for step size, and b means Burgers vector. At a tensile temperature of 500 • C, the ρ GND reaches its peak value of 2.66 × 10 14 m -2 . With increasing temperature, the ρ GND monotonically decreases, reaching a significantly lower value of 0.81 × 10 14 m -2 at 750 • C. Owing to the slipping or climbing of dislocations, sub-grain boundaries are formed within grains, evolving from small-angle to large-angle grain boundaries through the continuous absorption of dislocations generated during deformation. The decrease in dislocation density can be attributed to the DRX and DRV effect increases with the increase of temperature. arrangement of dislocations at the grain boundaries. Fig. 10c illustrates the high density of dislocations found at the interface between α and β grains. No dislocations were found to pass through the α and β interface, which may be because they do not satisfy the BOR, making it difficult for dislocations to cross the interface. Fig. 11 exhibits TEM images after tension at 650 • C. As depicted in Fig. 11, a microcrack can be observed, and the EDS mappings reveal that the microcrack is surrounded by Mo elements, demonstrating that the microcrack occurs within the β grain. Firstly, At high temperatures, β phase is softer than α phase, so the deformation first occurs in the β phase [37]. When β and adjacent α phases do not meet the Bugers orientation relation, the dislocation can't across the α/β interface, and stress concentration is formed at the interface [35]. Secondly, the β of the BCC structure has two more independent slip systems than the α phase of the HCP structure [38]. Hence, the β phase exhibits a greater deformation capacity than the α phase, manifesting that more plastic deformation and tearing exist within the β phase during the tensile process.

Fig. 12 shows the IPF map near the fracture surface after tensile testing at 650 • C, reconstructed β phase based on the BOR and the distribution of misorientation angles, respectively. According to the reconstructed β phase map, it can be found that the crack (white region) appears at the PBG boundary. Fig. 12b also shows a large amount of recrystallization grain. Fig. 12c is the distribution of misorientation angle obtained according to Fig. 12a. It can be found that the original BOR relationship has been destroyed, and most of the grain boundary angles are concentrated in the range of 0-15 • . During high-temperature deformation, the subgrain boundaries in the grain are caused by the sliding and climbing of the dislocation. With the increase of tensile strain, these subgrain boundaries eventually transform into grain boundaries.

Fig. 13 shows TEM images of a tensile sample at 750 • C. In contrast to the lamellar structure observed at 550 • C, numerous equiaxed α grains can be observed for the sample tested at 750 • C in Fig. 13a. This observation is consistent with EBSD results (Fig. 8f). The β phase is located within the interstices of these equiaxed α grains, exhibiting an equiaxed or discontinuous lamellar morphology. Furthermore, at 750 • C, the interaction between dislocations, such as clustering and climbing, becomes more pronounced, characterized by extensive dislocation forests and entanglements. The characteristics of dislocation lines are elongated and curved, distinct from the short dislocations observed at 550 • C. This difference is attributed to the reduction in shear modulus and the increase in enthalpy with rising temperature, which diminishes the line tension required to activate dislocations and the energy needed to promote cross-slip [39]. Moreover, dislocations are observed to traverse grain boundaries at high temperatures, thereby alleviating stress concentration at these interfaces. At high temperatures, the CRSS required to activate slip systems is lower than at room temperature [40,41]. As shown in Fig. 14, it can be observed that prismatic and pyramidal <a> with the Schmid factor ranging from 0.4 to 0.5 constitute the majority, which facilitates the activation of prismatic and pyramidal <a> slip, but the basal <a> slip is limited [42]. In other words, the activation of multiple slip systems contributes to a more uniform plastic deformation process. Furthermore, during high-temperature tensile deformation, grains tend to rotate in directions that facilitate easier slip deformation, thereby enhancing the sample's elongation and reducing the yield strength [43].

div.head: DRV and DRX behaviors
div.p: As shown in Fig. 5, there are two distinct types of tensile curves: one is that the flow stress decreases rapidly after reaching the peak, and the other is a slow decline. This can be attributed to work hardening and softening [44]. There are two types of softening mechanisms: DRV and DRX. During the tensile testing, the increase and accumulation of dislocations result in a rise in stress with the progression of strain. At 500 • C and 550 • C, the flow stress rapidly decreases after reaching peak. In the initial stage of tensile, the DRV process progresses slowly. The annihilation rate of dislocations is lower than their multiplication rate, causing the continuous rise of dislocation density, which is reflected as a gradual increase in flow stress on the tensile curve. After the flow stress reaches its peak, dislocation entanglement leads to stress concentration, resulting in the initiation of cracks and the occurrence of heterogeneous deformation, which subsequently causes rapid fracture of the sample. With the increase of temperature (650-750 • C), as the dislocation density reaches a critical value, the DRX eliminates dislocations through the transformation of high-angle grain boundaries, which results in softening. It was also noted that YS and UTS fell faster in the range of 650-750 • C, as shown in Fig. 6. This can be attributed to the major softening mechanism shift from DRV to DRX.

div.head: High-temperature softening behavior
div.p: It is well established that the peak stress depends on various factors, such as strain rate, testing temperature, and structural parameters [45]. However, dislocation density is the most crucial determinant of strength. As depicted in Fig. 9, the dislocation density is inversely proportional to the deformation temperature. Therefore, the dislocation density is the main factor affecting the strength.

Furthermore, the decrease of CRSS caused by temperature increase is another factor in the decrease of strength. Studies have shown that the type slip system has the highest proportion in titanium alloys, indicating that <a> slip is predominant during deformation [45]. The higher temperature, the greater <a>/<c + a> ratio, suggesting that higher temperatures are more conducive to <a> slip [46].

The transition in fracture mode at 650 • C highlights the significance of grain boundary strength as a crucial factor influencing material strength at elevated temperatures. Below 650 • C, higher grain boundary strength than grain strength, whereas, at 650 • C, the intergranular fracture shows obvious softening of grain boundaries. As a fundamental property of grain boundaries, the grain boundary energy typically varies with temperature and significantly affects the performance of the sample [47]. Studies indicate that the Read-Shockley theory exhibits high concordance between calculated results and experimental outcomes within the low angle range of 0 • -10 • [48]. Accordingly, the Read-Shockley method was employed in this experiment to calculate the grain boundary energy at various temperatures. The Read-Shockley formula is as follows [49]:
where G represents the shear modulus, the Burgers vector b is 0.3 nm, θ is the grain boundary orientation angle and the Poisson ratio v is 0.37.
The shear modulus G can be taken [50]:

With the elevation of tensile temperature, the atomic spacing increases and the elastic modulus decreases. Fig. 15 illustrates the variation of shear modulus with the temperature and the distribution of 0-10 • misorientation and average angle at tensile temperatures ranging from 550 to 700 • C. As the tensile temperature rises, the grain boundary angle decreases progressively. The calculated values of grain boundary energy are presented in Table 3. Therefore, grain boundary strength decreases with increasing temperature. It has also been observed that the grain boundary energy significantly decreases at temperatures up to 650 • C.

div.head: High-temperature tensile properties
div.p: The annealed TA15 alloy exhibits better high-temperature mechanical properties (YS = 564 MPa, EL = 18.5 %) at 500 • C compared to the forged TA15 alloy (YS = 553 MPa, EL = 16.82 %) [51]. Furthermore, owing to the exceptionally low oxidation rate of the TA15 alloy at 500 • C, it is capable of sustained operation in such an environment. Consequently, the alloy meets the application requirements in traditional fields, such as for load-bearing components in a 500 • C environment. It also fulfils the criteria for short-term use in the temperature range of 500-600 • C. It is important to note that, as mentioned above when the operating temperature exceeds 600 • C, the enhanced DRV effect and the rapid decline in grain boundary strength result in a significant reduction in strength. Therefore, the TA15 alloy is not suitable for applications at temperatures above 600 • C.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, the softening mechanism and deformation behavior of annealed L-PBF TA15 alloy at high temperature were investigated. The primary research focus encompassed the analysis of GNDs, the activation of slip systems, fracture modes and the strength of grain boundaries. The main conclusions are as follows:

figure.figDesc: Fig. 12. (a) IPF map near tensile fracture at 650 • C; (b) reconstructed β phases IPF map; (c) misorientation angle distribution.

figure.head: Fig. 14 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 14. Histogram of Schmid factor distribution at 500-650 • C.

At 500 • C, the TA15 alloy processed by L-PBF demonstrates exceptional high-temperature tensile properties, with a tensile strength of 686 ± 12 MPa and an elongation of 18.5 ± 2.1 %. However, as the testing temperature increases, its workhardening capacity and yield strength progressively decrease, while the elongation rate gradually increases. (2) The strength of the grain boundary decreases as the tensile temperature increases. At temperatures below 600 • C, the fracture pattern is transgranular, while at temperatures above 650 • C, the fracture pattern changes to intergranular fracture. (3) The sample exhibits a pronounced softening phenomenon at 600 • C. During the initial stage of tensile deformation, work hardening due to dislocation density remains the predominant mechanism. As the tensile temperature increases, the DRX effect intensifies, and the softening process becomes increasingly evident. div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
